clubsdeuce 160907530021 "2017-05-21 13:07:42 GMT" http://clubsdeuce.tumblr.com/post/160907530021/tinygayrobin-thedemonsurfer "tinygayrobin:  thedemonsurfer:  bringsyouwings:  mysticorset:  the-original-bravo:  theblacklittlemermaid:  daughterofdiaspora:  my mom taught me the therapeutic power of cleaning. open all the windows. throw out the old. wipe down the entire house. burn some incense. roast some coffee. then rest. that way the tears from last night don’t feel as heavy.   She just wanted you to clean the house  No it’s actually been studied and proven that for people with anxiety and depression that it’s really good for us it gives us a sense of control
column3: and being well grounded. It allows to make a new place out of the old and is really relaxing  It is such a catch-22
column4: that cleaning when you are depressed (and likely less able to gather the executive functioning to do so) also alleviates it. After having a good clean
column5: I always feel more in control and less stressed. It’s the getting started that is the hardest part. The good news is
column6: even a tiny bit of cleaning has a positive effect
column7: so start with what you can manage.  Even if you just clean up the immediate area around you
column8: even if you clean a little at a time or spaced out over days
column9: you’ll feel lighter.  This!! Even if all you can do is put three dishes in the dishwasher
column10: or move the dirty laundry pile to outside the laundry door
column11: or throw out that box of leftovers that have been sitting in the fridge for 2 weeks it counts.  My therapy professor always gets his patients to just wipe the bathroom mirror when they’re feeling that way. Just the mirror
column12: nothing more. But then by the time his patients are done with the mirror
column14: I was already in the bathroom
column15: so I did the sink and tub too.” And before they know it
column16: they’ve cleaned an entire bathroom. " False text

clubsdeuce 148176878701 "2016-07-30 02:24:25 GMT" http://clubsdeuce.tumblr.com/post/148176878701/nyssa-whitehead-is-creating-stories-and-art "northerngrail: Hey everyone! This is my post about my Patreon!As most of you who follow me probably know by now
column2: I am an author. I write for a living. Now as much enjoyment as I get just from writing
column3: I’m sure that we can all agree that it isn’t very viable to try and just write for the sake of writing. That’s where all of you come in. You all likely know how Patreon works but I’ll explain for those that don’t: You can pledge certain amounts of money to me every month and in return you’ll get rewards depending on what tier you pledged on. For my Patreon that can range from being able to see posts that only pledgers can
column4: to getting a certain kind of commission every month. There are more specifics at the link above! Now
column5: please keep in mind that my Patreon will have NSFW works at times
column6: as well as touching on sensitive material. I will be certain to label everything accordingly
column7: so please pay heed to those warnings! I really
column8: really want to be able to turn my writing into a full time job. You can pledge as little as one dollar and still be able to look at all the exclusive works I’ll be putting out. And even if you can’t pledge anything
column9: you can still help me out by reblogging and letting people who might be interested know about it. Honestly no matter what you do to help out
column10: thank you from the bottom of my heart. " False link

clubsdeuce 126474703866 "2015-08-12 02:41:17 GMT" http://clubsdeuce.tumblr.com/post/126474703866/creator-craig-mccracken-on-the-visual "wingedartist28:  Creator Craig McCracken On the Visual Inventiveness of Wander Over Yonder  Wander Over Yonder is deceptively simple. The bubbly animated series
column2: which began airing on Disney XD in 2013
column3: follows Wander (voiced by Wreck-It Ralph star Jack McBrayer)
column4: a sunny intergalactic traveler with a floppy hat who travels across the universe with his trusty steed Sylvia (April Winchell). They get into wacky misadventures
column5: run afoul of the evil Lord Hater (Keith Ferguson) and encounter all manner of strange creature. But they do it with smiles on their faces and a spring in their step. And while the basic setup of Wander Over Yonder may seem fairly standard for an animated kids’ show
column7: particularly with its approach to visual and narrative storytelling. The entire show looks like it was filmed from inside a black light poster
column8: seemingly inspired by prog rock album covers from the 1970s (Wander definitely has the look and feel of an optimistic folk musician). Often times the visuals are pushed to almost experimental extremes
column9: and the narratives blow past commonplace formality for something more charming and uncommon. Tonight
column10: one of the episodes that really exemplifies Wander Over Yonder’s commitment to visual and narrative inventiveness
column11: airs on Disney XD. Entitled “The Breakfast
column12: ” which sees the lovable Wander waking up and getting ready for his day
column13: along with Lord Hater getting ready at the same time. The entire episode is presented in split-screen
column14: with action taking place on both sides of the device
column15: with jokes playing off one another and occasionally interacting. If you want to know what makes Wander Over Yonder so special
column16: this 11-minute episode is a good place to start. “It was about trying to create this world of science fiction before Star Wars
column17: ” Wander Over Yonder creator McCracken explained. “So everything before 1977
column18: everything from old science fiction book covers
column20: to early Terry Gilliam animation. And it’s also heavily influenced by Muppets. I really like the simplicity of Jim Henson designs and I try to incorporate that.” And while Wander Over Yonder flawlessly combines gentle surrealism with actual danger
column21: McCracken said a chief imperative towered above all others: the show’s inherent silliness
column22: and that the show’s sweetness influenced its look. “It’s shamelessly cartoon-y and we always embrace the silliness. There are deeper stories and the characters have real emotions and real feelings but the overall tone of the show is fun. So we wanted to come up with a design style that was fun and cool to look at.” To that end they created a “lava lamp” aesthetic and applied it to everything. “It’s all gloopy and soft and there’s not a lot of hard edges or sharp angles.” It’s true that everything on Wander Over Yonder looks super huggable
column23: even if it’s supposed to be something scary and weird. When coming up with the split-screen episode
column24: McCracken had to ask himself some questions. “The way I always approach every one of my cartoons is by saying
column25: What’s something that we haven’t done? What’s a fun experiment? And I think of every cartoon not as individual episodes but as little sketches or little films. So it was a matter of noting that Hater is an eternal pessimist who has everything handed to him and Wander is this eternal optimist who lives out in nature and has to work hard for everything. So we thought it’d be a neat character study to do a point/counter-point of how they get breakfast in the morning.” We mentioned that we couldn’t think of any animated series that had done something like this; McCracken couldn’t either. Not that it fazed him. “That was what I got really excited about. Can we do this? Can we make two simultaneous cartoons where each joke plays point/counter-point? It was really tricky to figure out because the one thing we needed to do was direct the audience with where to look at any given time. We didn’t want to play both of them as noise. We needed to lead you to choose a side. So all of that was very meticulously crafted.” Something rendered entirely in split-screen is pretty unheard of. When we watched “The Breakfast” episode of Wander Over Yonder
column26: we immediately thought of the work of suspense director Brian De Palma
column28: particularly in the ‘70s (the same period of pop art that Wander Over Yonder references)
column29: made extensive use of split-screen. But McCracken’s reference point wasn’t so heady. “I had recently seen some commercials that had did that
column31: we’re sold. The kind of playful experimentation presented in “The Breakfast” isn’t a fluke
column32: either. McCracken points out that there were two episodes in the show’s first season (“The Day” and “The Night”)
column34: the last frame of each one loops up into the next one. So you could watch those cartoons in a perpetual loop forever.” He also points out to the “Rashomon-style” approach to the Christmas and Halloween episodes of the show last season (“The Gift” and “The Giftening”)
column35: where Wander’s charitable good deeds are seen
column37: as truly terrifying. “We took the same story but looked at the other side of it
column39: the series’ intoxicating mixture of far-out visuals and bold storytelling isn’t going to stop anytime soon. McCracken is particularly excited about an extra-long musical episode (set to air sometime next year). “We did a full-on 22-minute musical and what we wanted to do was treat it like a real
column41: ” he enthused. “So we did it like they used to do it with the Sherman Brothers where the composer was in the story room with a keyboard while we were watching the story. So we would break it with our composer
column42: Andy Bean. It’s something we’re incredibly proud of. It’s incredibly ambitious. It’s going to be a lot of fun.” Like we said: you can search the entire galaxy
column43: but there isn’t a show quite like Wander Over Yonder. New
column44: increasingly brilliant episodes of Wander Over Yonder air on Monday nights at 9 p.m. on Disney XD. They’re worth the journey. " False link

column2: DO NOT throw the trash away in their garbage’s. The employees get written up
